article_title: Tell me, child: What are you afraid of?
article_text:
Tell me, child: What are you afraid of?

Photo: Andrew Harrer, Bloomberg Obamacare made the list.

You may be an anxious person. I understand that. You may allow your fears to march across your brain at night, permitting you to pick just one and then obsess over it. What is that spot on my toe, you might wonder, selecting your worry from among the many options listed under “Health and wellness worries.”

article_metadata.sailthru.author: By Jon Carroll
article_metadata.description: What is that spot on my toe, you might wonder, selecting your worry from among the many options listed under “Health and wellness worries.”  [...] surveys in general never mention that qualification, which skews toward housebound thrill seekers and the extremely lonely.  The results are presented in several ways, mostly notably in an illustration, in the highly detailed form favored by architects pitching their ambitious plans for an amusement park.  There are 11 different “lands,” each with its own color and symbol, ranging from Daily Life (orange; sun emerging from clouds) through Government (brown; Doric column) to Natural Disasters (purple; tornado).  The next two, essentially in a dead heat with cyberterrorism, were corporate tracking of personal information and terrorist attacks.  The bottom four in the top 10 were thematically linked: identity theft, economic collapse, running out of money in the future, and credit card fraud.  Put these all together, and I think it’s fair to infer that Americans fear that government corruption is taking money from their pockets.  Maybe they’d go after identity thieves instead of Internet gambling sites; maybe they’d demand companies have stronger security precautions against data-harvesting criminals; maybe they’d punish too-big-to-fail executives instead of allowing them to rule the economy; maybe they’d lower medical care costs, including prescription drugs, so then we all wouldn’t run out of money in the future.  Giant machines designed to enrich the people who make giant machines; giant machines designed to destroy democracy by making voting irrelevant.  Obamacare (35.7 percent afraid or very afraid) is right between war (35.8) and illness (34.4), which doesn’t seem to make any sense to me — if you’re afraid of sickness, you should like Obamacare, which helps a lot of people avoid sickness, or recover from it.  [...] down the list we have reptiles (33.0 percent), global warming (30.7), trusting artificial intelligence to do work (25.8), loneliness (22.0), drones (20.4), whites no longer a majority (18.2), gossip (9.6) and zombies (8.5).
